content:
A SPECTRE IS haunting the rich world. It is the spectre of ungovernability. “Ungovernability in lass="word-wrap-span">Italy is a great risk,” lass="word-wrap-span">averred its former prime minister, lass="word-wrap-span">Matteo Renzi, in 2017. “It will be impossible to govern lass="word-wrap-span">Spain until they lass="word-wrap-span">face the political problem in Catalonia,” predicted the spokeswoman of the Catalan regional government in February (just before that government was closed down). Emmanuel lass="word-wrap-span">Macron, for whom to govern is to reform, warned that “lass="word-wrap-span">France is not a reformable country”, evolass="word-wrap-span">king the spirit of lass="word-wrap-span">General de lass="word-wrap-span">Gaulle who once asked how anyone could govern a nation with 246 lass="word-wrap-span">kinds of cheese.

lass="word-wrap-span">When you survey the political landscape of rich countries, you see an unusual amount of lass="word-wrap-span">chaos and upheaval. lass="word-wrap-span">Prague has seen the largest lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations since the overthrow of lass="word-wrap-span">communism. lass="word-wrap-span">More than a quarter of the current parliaments in lass="word-wrap-span">Europe were elected in polls that were called early. In lass="word-wrap-span">Britain the mother of parliaments has been at the lass="word-wrap-span">gin bottle and opinion polls everywhere show increasing numbers of people losing patience with lass="word-wrap-span">democratic niceties and lass="word-wrap-span">hankering after a strongman.

lass="word-wrap-span">But experiencing protests or having weak governments does not make a country ungovernable. lass="word-wrap-span">Moreover, as lass="word-wrap-span">Tolstoy might have written, each ungovernable country is ungovernable in its own way. lass="word-wrap-span">The problems of lass="word-wrap-span">Italy, lass="word-wrap-span">Spain lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Britain are all different. So what, if anything, does ungovernability mean when applied to democracies? lass="word-wrap-span">And if it is a problem, is it worse now than in lass="word-wrap-span">The recent past?

Ungovernability can be thought of in four ways. No lass="word-wrap-span">Western country is ungovernable in every one. lass="word-wrap-span">But there are a few features that exist in more than one country and a few countries that look ungovernable in more than one sense.

lass="word-wrap-span">First, some countries cannot form a stable government either because (in lass="word-wrap-span">First-past-the-post systems) the largest party does not commlass="word-wrap-span">And a majority in parliament, or because (in countries with lass="word-wrap-span">coalitions) parties cannot organise a stable alliance on the lass="word-wrap-span">basis of election results. lass="word-wrap-span">Spain has had three elections since the end of 2015 lass="word-wrap-span">And may have to call a fourth following its failure to negotiate a new lass="word-wrap-span">coalition. In lass="word-wrap-span">Britain an election in 2017 stripped the ruling lass="word-wrap-span">Conservatives of their majority lass="word-wrap-span">And their subsequent period in office has been tumultuous. In both countries, stable two-party systems have given way to wobbly four- or five-party ones. (lass="word-wrap-span">And both, lass="word-wrap-span">incidentally, have seen the collapse of large regional governments, in Catalonia lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Northern Irellass="word-wrap-span">And.)

In the 28 lass="word-wrap-span">European lass="word-wrap-span">Union countries, eight of the most recent legislative elections were snap polls, called before the end of the normal parliamentary term. lass="word-wrap-span">This is not a trivial share, though it does not suggest widespread lass="word-wrap-span">chaos, either.

lass="word-wrap-span">Joining up is hard to do

lass="word-wrap-span">More common, countries with lass="word-wrap-span">coalition governments have suffered unusually protracted negotiations. lass="word-wrap-span">Sweden’s lasted four months ending in lass="word-wrap-span">January 2019; lass="word-wrap-span">The country now has an lass="word-wrap-span">ineffective minority government. lass="word-wrap-span">Finland held an election in lass="word-wrap-span">April and it took until lass="word-wrap-span">The end of lass="word-wrap-span">May to create a left-right lass="word-wrap-span">coalition. lass="word-wrap-span">These cases pale in comparison with lass="word-wrap-span">The eight months that it took to produce a lass="word-wrap-span">Czech government in 2018, to say nothing of lass="word-wrap-span">The record 535 days that lass="word-wrap-span">Belgium lass="word-wrap-span">endured without a government in 2010-11. lass="word-wrap-span">After its vote in 2018, lass="word-wrap-span">Italy did manage to lass="word-wrap-span">cobble togelass="word-wrap-span">Ther a lass="word-wrap-span">coalition between populist right and populist left, though lass="word-wrap-span">They cannot stand one anolass="word-wrap-span">Ther. lass="word-wrap-span">These countries should probably be called precarious, ralass="word-wrap-span">Ther than ungovernable.

lass="word-wrap-span">Next, ungovernability can mean that governments fail to pass lass="word-wrap-span">basic laws on which the operations of the state depend. lass="word-wrap-span">Spain’s could not pass a budget this year, triggering the election in lass="word-wrap-span">April. lass="word-wrap-span">Italy did pass its budget for 2019, but by lass="word-wrap-span">busting the financial limits imposed by the EU, though lass="word-wrap-span">confrontation has so far been avoided.

lass="word-wrap-span">Broken by Brexit

lass="word-wrap-span">Britain has seen an unprecedented failure: a thrice-repeated defeat by huge marlass="word-wrap-span">gins in the lass="word-wrap-span">House of lass="word-wrap-span">Commons on the most important issue of the day, Brexit. lass="word-wrap-span">Had lass="word-wrap-span">This happened at any other time, the government would have resigned, precipitating an election. As it was, the defeats triggered a contest for leadership of the lass="word-wrap-span">Conservative lass="word-wrap-span">Party, resulting in a government which expects to crash out of the EU without an agreement, pitted against a parliament determined to prevent such a thing happening. lass="word-wrap-span">This is an lass="word-wrap-span">extraordinary turn of events in a system which is not supposed to permit divided government. If lass="word-wrap-span">Britain is sliding towards ungovernability will depend on whether it does crash out and what happens at the expected early election. At the moment, with a one- or two-seat majority, the government is running on lass="word-wrap-span">fumes.

lass="word-wrap-span">But the home of failure to pass meaningful laws is the lass="word-wrap-span">United lass="word-wrap-span">States, where both lass="word-wrap-span">Republicans and lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats have given up on passing legislation until after the presidential election of 2020. lass="word-wrap-span">This continues a long-standing failure. lass="word-wrap-span">Appropriation (budget) bills routinely fail to be lass="word-wrap-span">approved on time. lass="word-wrap-span">Between 2016 and 2018, lass="word-wrap-span">Republicans controlled both branches of government lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">failed in their main legislative goal, to repeal the lass="word-wrap-span">Affordable lass="word-wrap-span">Care lass="word-wrap-span">Act (“Obamalass="word-wrap-span">Care”), and did not try to win lass="word-wrap-span">approval for a promised deal to improve lass="word-wrap-span">America’s crumbling lass="word-wrap-span">infrastructure. lass="word-wrap-span">America is not ungovernable in most senses of the term lass="word-wrap-span">But its legislature and lass="word-wrap-span">executive are locked into paralysis.

A third aspect of ungovernability is lass="word-wrap-span">The systematic lass="word-wrap-span">corruption of constitutional norms, malass="word-wrap-span">king political processes lass="word-wrap-span">haphazard or lass="word-wrap-span">arbitrary. lass="word-wrap-span">This does not lass="word-wrap-span">always make countries ungovernable. lass="word-wrap-span">Sometimes, as recently in lass="word-wrap-span">Hungary, for example, it does lass="word-wrap-span">The opposite, increasing state power at lass="word-wrap-span">The expense of lass="word-wrap-span">democratic checks and balances. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">The undermining of norms can also lass="word-wrap-span">hamper decision-malass="word-wrap-span">king, as in lass="word-wrap-span">Britain. lass="word-wrap-span">There, lass="word-wrap-span">cabinet responsibility and party lass="word-wrap-span">discipline have broken down, ministers break lass="word-wrap-span">The ministerial code of conduct and traditions of parliamentary procedure, such as holding a lass="word-wrap-span">Queen’s lass="word-wrap-span">Speech to outline legislative proposals, are ignored.

lass="word-wrap-span">America is not quite as bad. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">President lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump shut down lass="word-wrap-span">The federal government twice in a year—compared with once in Barack Obama’s eight years. lass="word-wrap-span">The second lass="word-wrap-span">Trump shutdown, in 2018-19, was lass="word-wrap-span">The longest in history. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump has lass="word-wrap-span">flouted lass="word-wrap-span">Congress over a tax law lass="word-wrap-span">And urged his administration to resist lass="word-wrap-span">Congressional requests for information. lass="word-wrap-span">The former British lass="word-wrap-span">amlass="word-wrap-span">bassador to Washington called his administration lass="word-wrap-span">dysfunctional, unpredictable, lass="word-wrap-span">faction-riven, lass="word-wrap-span">diplomatically lass="word-wrap-span">clumsy lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">inept. lass="word-wrap-span">And that is lass="word-wrap-span">The view of lass="word-wrap-span">America’s friends. lass="word-wrap-span">America’s political system is not designed to operate smoothly. lass="word-wrap-span">But it is becoming lass="word-wrap-span">dysfunctional in ways lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">framers never lass="word-wrap-span">envisaged.

lass="word-wrap-span">Western countries are not ungovernable in lass="word-wrap-span">The sense of paralysed by riots or lass="word-wrap-span">crises. lass="word-wrap-span">They have not lost control of lass="word-wrap-span">The streets. lass="word-wrap-span">Nor are lass="word-wrap-span">They lass="word-wrap-span">Congo. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">Their governments are riven by lass="word-wrap-span">disputes and are too weak to lass="word-wrap-span">implement big reforms—to pensions, say, or social care. lass="word-wrap-span">They are not impossible to govern in lass="word-wrap-span">The sense of lass="word-wrap-span">chaotic or lass="word-wrap-span">anarchic lass="word-wrap-span">But more than a few are ungovernable in lass="word-wrap-span">The sense that lass="word-wrap-span">Their governments cannot do anything of importance.

lass="word-wrap-span">lastly, the past year has seen a return to the streets of mass lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations. In lass="word-wrap-span">France, the gilets jaunes (yellow jackets), a populist lass="word-wrap-span">grassroots movement, have blocked roads lass="word-wrap-span">And staged some of the most violent lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations the country has seen since 1968. In lass="word-wrap-span">Britain lass="word-wrap-span">campaigners against Brexit claimed 1m people joined a lass="word-wrap-span">demonstration in London in lass="word-wrap-span">March 2019, which would make it one of lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s largest-ever rallies. lass="word-wrap-span">Prague has seen the largest lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations since the lass="word-wrap-span">Velvet revolution of 1989. lass="word-wrap-span">And there have been smaller anti-government rallies in lass="word-wrap-span">Spain, lass="word-wrap-span">Serbia, lass="word-wrap-span">Hungary lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">Slovakia in 2018-19.

lass="word-wrap-span">The nature of lass="word-wrap-span">These lass="word-wrap-span">demonstrations, however, is a reminder of what today’s ungovernability is not. It is not mob rule. No one is burning down lass="word-wrap-span">The presidential palace or executing lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">king. lass="word-wrap-span">Protests in lass="word-wrap-span">Western capitals have mostly been placid compared with lass="word-wrap-span">The 1960s and 1970s. lass="word-wrap-span">During riots after lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">assassination of lass="word-wrap-span">Martin Lulass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">king in 1968, machineguns were posted on lass="word-wrap-span">The steps of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Capitol.

lass="word-wrap-span">That point of comparison suggests an odd feature of lass="word-wrap-span">contemporary politics: it turns lass="word-wrap-span">The experience of lass="word-wrap-span">The 1970s upside down. lass="word-wrap-span">Then, lass="word-wrap-span">Inflation was rampant, unemployment high and strikes common. lass="word-wrap-span">There were riots and lass="word-wrap-span">assassinations and, in lass="word-wrap-span">America, lass="word-wrap-span">conscription into an unpopular war. lass="word-wrap-span">Yet, with exceptions such as lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Watergate scandal, lass="word-wrap-span">The business of government continued to rumble along. lass="word-wrap-span">Within a couple of years of lass="word-wrap-span">The riots in 1968, Richard lass="word-wrap-span">Nixon had set up lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Environmental lass="word-wrap-span">Protection lass="word-wrap-span">Agency; de lass="word-wrap-span">Gaulle won a legislative election just after lass="word-wrap-span">The Paris événements. lass="word-wrap-span">Paul Keating, later Australia’s prime minister, said of his country’s government in lass="word-wrap-span">The 1980s lass="word-wrap-span">That “lass="word-wrap-span">The dogs may lass="word-wrap-span">bark lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">caravan moves on” (ie, lass="word-wrap-span">The government kept going, critics notwithstanding). lass="word-wrap-span">Now, matters seem to be reversed. lass="word-wrap-span">Inflation is tamed, unemployment is low and wages are inching up. lass="word-wrap-span">But governments are stalemated. lass="word-wrap-span">Compared with lass="word-wrap-span">The 1970s, societies are less lass="word-wrap-span">disorderly lass="word-wrap-span">But politics is more so.

lass="word-wrap-span">Perhaps this will prove short-lived. lass="word-wrap-span">Maybe politicians are just lass="word-wrap-span">facing a temporary double-whammy of unpopularity. lass="word-wrap-span">Voters are not giving them credit for economic recovery and are angry about the costs of lass="word-wrap-span">austerity. If so, governments might one day reap electoral rewards and normal lass="word-wrap-span">governance will resume.

lass="word-wrap-span">The party’s over

lass="word-wrap-span">But longer-term trends seem against that, notably the secular decline of large political parties which has gone lass="word-wrap-span">furthest in lass="word-wrap-span">Europe (see chart). At their height, the two largest parties in lass="word-wrap-span">Britain, lass="word-wrap-span">Spain and lass="word-wrap-span">Germany were winning 80-90% of the vote. lass="word-wrap-span">Now, they are down to two-thirds or less.

In 1960, 15% of lass="word-wrap-span">electorates in western lass="word-wrap-span">Europe were lass="word-wrap-span">affiliated with a party. lass="word-wrap-span">Now the share is below 5%. lass="word-wrap-span">Britain’s two big parties were once the largest lass="word-wrap-span">civic organisations in the country. lass="word-wrap-span">Now their combined membership is less than that of the lass="word-wrap-span">Royal lass="word-wrap-span">Society for the lass="word-wrap-span">Protection of lass="word-wrap-span">Birds.

lass="word-wrap-span">Membership of unions lass="word-wrap-span">And churches has fallen, marlass="word-wrap-span">ginalising the institutions that lass="word-wrap-span">buttressed the centre-left lass="word-wrap-span">And centre-right, respectively. lass="word-wrap-span">And, except in lass="word-wrap-span">America, voters are more lass="word-wrap-span">fickle. lass="word-wrap-span">Alesslass="word-wrap-span">Andro Chiaramonte of the lass="word-wrap-span">University of lass="word-wrap-span">Florence lass="word-wrap-span">And Vincenzo lass="word-wrap-span">Emanuele of Luiss lass="word-wrap-span">University in lass="word-wrap-span">Rome found that 8% of lass="word-wrap-span">European voters changed their votes between national elections in 1946-68; in 1969-91, 9% did so; in 1992-2015, 13% changed their minds.

lass="word-wrap-span">Everywhere, parties are finding it harder to recruit and retain members and to mobilise voters. Parties are lass="word-wrap-span">The organising forces of parliamentary democracy. lass="word-wrap-span">They pick candidates, lass="word-wrap-span">approve manifestos and get out lass="word-wrap-span">The vote. lass="word-wrap-span">Coalitions usually revolve around one large party. If parties continue to decline, political systems are likely to become at least more lass="word-wrap-span">fluid, and at worst harder to govern.

eg2: The challenge is to supply sufficient amounts of Affordable energy to power our lives and build an energy system that can sustain future generations.

No one everyone believed that the renal dialysis technology was a unique kind of technology, and it was because of that uniqueness that we believed it was .
没有人认为，肾透析技术是一种独特的技术，而且由于这种独特性，我们就认为它是负担得起的。
We’re also making college more  for millions of students, and revitalizing our community colleges, so that folks can get the training they need for the careers they want.
我们还让数百万学生更加负担得起大学学费，重振我们的社区学院，这样人们便可以获得他们期望的职业所需的技能培训。
